<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/32  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 265, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Theory (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the core of a transformer. It is made from thin sheets of iron.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 98, 665, 335]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 351, 591, 369]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 146, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
There are 200 sheets of iron in the core of the transformer. The thickness of the core is \(50 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 593, 432]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average thickness of **one** sheet of iron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 555, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
average thickness of one sheet = .................................................... mm [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 146, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 588, 816, 606]]<|/det|>
The density of the iron in the core is \(7.65 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\). The mass of the core is \(1377 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 619, 430, 637]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume of the core.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 749, 920, 768]]<|/det|>
<form>volume = .................................................... $\text{cm}^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 781, 144, 799]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 781, 578, 799]]<|/det|>
State the name of a device used to measure mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 812, 920, 829]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 842, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows a barrier used at a car park. The beam can be raised and lowered by a man rotating it about its pivot.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 114, 771, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 246, 591, 264]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3.1] (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 276, 144, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 276, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
The weight of the beam is \(150\mathrm{N}\). This acts at a distance of \(1.8\mathrm{m}\) from the pivot as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 322, 685, 341]]<|/det|>
Calculate the moment of the weight of the beam about the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 354, 475, 371]]<|/det|>
Include the correct unit in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 481, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
<form>moment of weight of beam = .................................. unit ................ [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 511, 146, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
When the weight \(W\) of the heavy weight acts at a distance of \(0.6 \text{m}\) from the pivot, the barrier is horizontal and balanced as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 543, 900, 577]]<|/det|>
The man raises the barrier and the heavy weight slips to a distance of \(0.8 \text{m}\) from the pivot. This causes a problem for the man trying to lower the barrier.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 801, 607]]<|/det|>
Describe and explain the problem this causes for the man lowering the barrier.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 745, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 775, 920, 792]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 752, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates energy changes when a ball rolls down a curved track.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 824, 120]]<|/det|>
The student holds the ball at a starting point on the curved track, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 128, 751, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 276, 532, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 307, 920, 341]]<|/det|>
The ball is released. It rolls down the track, up the other side to the stopping point and then back down again.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 146, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 354, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
Describe the energy changes that take place as the ball rolls from the starting point to the stopping point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 492, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 523, 146, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 771, 542]]<|/det|>
The height of the stopping point is less than the height of the starting point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
Describe how the principle of conservation of energy explains the difference between the height of the stopping point and the height of the starting point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 799, 609]]<|/det|>
The battery is charged using a transformer connected to an a.c. power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 622, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
The primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) to the transformer is \(234\mathrm{V}\) and the secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer is \(18\mathrm{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 625, 686]]<|/det|>
The number of turns on the primary coil \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) is 2470 turns.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 699, 613, 717]]<|/det|>
Calculate the number of turns on the secondary coil \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 821, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
<form>N_{\mathrm{s}} = ............................................................ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 853, 920, 871]]<|/det|>
